November 1, 1933.
Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER,
). Sir.
The proposal of Tau Beta Pi,
reported in your issue of October
31st, that the undergraduate curriculum in Engineering be extended
Year or more for the purpose of
including additional cultural subjects, voices a need which has been
long recognized and frequently discussed. There can be no question
of the enormous advantage to a
Professional man of a wide knowledge of the world's literature, art,
history, languages and politics.
Cites Attempted Plans

Engineering schools have been
thoroughly alive to this need and
various efforts have been made to
fleet it. In some cases the cultural
subjects are placed in the standard
four-year undergraduate program,
and five-year programs have already
been attempted (as at Columbia),
although these have not been successful. Some of the practical difficulties have recently been pointed
at the Tau Beta Pi meeting.
'undamentally, they may be reduced
to two; first, the length of time required to give underlying scientific
training, and beyond that the professional courses needed to cover
the enormous modern expanse of
any branch of engineering, and
second and more important, the urge
!or a general education cannot be
instilled by the mere provision of
Cultural courses taken in parallel
with professional courses. This

Three new volumes have been
added to the publications of The
Johns Hopkins Press. Prepared
under the direction of The Institute
of Law of The Johns Hopkins University are The Waiver of Jury
Trial in Criminal Cases in Ohio, by
Kenneth J. Martin, and The Mayors' Courts of Hamilton County,
Ohio by Paul F. Douglass, Ph.D.
Philip Mazzei, Friend of Jefferson
by Richard Cecil Gorlick is the third
book.
Mr. Martin's report "undertakes
to present information concerning
the results of waiver in felony cases
in Ohio, a jurisdiction, which, like
many others, has only recently
adopted the practice."

Sweeping across the finish line
in the record time of 21 minutes, 58
seconds last Saturday, Johnny King
led his Hopkins teammates to a decisive victory over the St. John's
harriers, 20-38. King, whose performances during the past two years
have been consistently outstanding,
eclipsed the former record for the
472-mile Homewood course set in
1927 by Dick Gwynn.
The score itself provided a new
record, for it was the first time in
four years that the meet was decided by more than one point. Previous to Saturday, Hopkins had
been on the losing end of these
closely-contested battles.

November 1, 1933.
Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER,
). Sir.
The proposal of Tau Beta Pi,
reported in your issue of October
31st, that the undergraduate curriculum in Engineering be extended
Year or more for the purpose of
including additional cultural subjects, voices a need which has been
long recognized and frequently discussed. There can be no question
of the enormous advantage to a
Professional man of a wide knowledge of the world's literature, art,
history, languages and politics.
Cites Attempted Plans

Engineering schools have been
thoroughly alive to this need and
various efforts have been made to
fleet it. In some cases the cultural
subjects are placed in the standard
four-year undergraduate program,
and five-year programs have already
been attempted (as at Columbia),
although these have not been successful. Some of the practical difficulties have recently been pointed
at the Tau Beta Pi meeting.
'undamentally, they may be reduced
to two; first, the length of time required to give underlying scientific
training, and beyond that the professional courses needed to cover

any branch of engineering, and
second and more important, the urge

with professional courses. This

the results of waiver in felony cases
in Ohio, a jurisdiction, which, like
many others, has only recently
adopted the practice."

Sweeping across the finish line
in the record time of 21 minutes, 58
seconds last Saturday, Johnny King
led his Hopkins teammates to a decisive victory over the St. John's
harriers, 20-38. King, whose performances during the past two years
have been consistently outstanding,
eclipsed the former record for the
472-mile Homewood course set in
1927 by Dick Gwynn.
The score itself provided a new
record, for it was the first time in
four years that the meet was decided by more than one point. Previous to Saturday, Hopkins had
been on the losing end of these
closely-contested battles.
